name: Act Utilitarianism (Hedonistic)
description: Right action is what maximizes overall happiness/pleasure (and minimizes suffering) impartially. Moral evaluation is outcome-first; rules are heuristics.

name: Rule Consequentialism
primary_source: Brad Hooker — Ideal Code, Real World
description: Acts are right when they conform to the set of rules whose general acceptance would have the best consequences. More rule-shaped than act utilitarianism, but still outcome-grounded.

name: Preference Utilitarianism
description: Right action maximizes the satisfaction of preferences/interests impartially. Still aggregative and outcome-first, but value is modeled as preference fulfillment.

name: Kantian Deontology
primary_source: Immanuel Kant — Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals
description: Morality is grounded in rational autonomy and universal law. Wrongdoing is constraint-first (not outcome-maximizing). Persons must be treated as ends.

name: Rossian Pluralist Deontology
primary_source: W.D. Ross — The Right and the Good
description: Multiple irreducible duties (fidelity, nonmaleficence, justice, etc.) known by intuition. Conflicts are resolved by judgment; no single master principle.

name: Scanlonian Contractualism
primary_source: T.M. Scanlon — What We Owe to Each Other
description: An act is wrong if it would be disallowed by principles no one could reasonably reject. Constraint-shaped and person-centered; not a welfare-sum.

name: Rawlsian Justice as Fairness
primary_source: John Rawls — A Theory of Justice
description: Principles of justice are those free and equal persons would choose under fair conditions (veil of ignorance). Institution-focused; priority rules matter.

name: Aristotelian Virtue Ethics
description: Ethics is chiefly about forming excellent character and practical wisdom oriented to human flourishing. Rules are subordinate to phronesis.

name: Stoic Virtue Ethics
description: Virtue is the only true good; living according to reason/nature is central. Strong constraints; externals are ‘indifferents.’

name: Care Ethics
description: Moral life is rooted in attentive responsiveness within relationships. Particularity, context, and caring practices outrank abstract impartial rules.

name: Confucian Role Ethics
description: Ethics centers on cultivating virtue through roles, ritual propriety (li), and humane concern (ren). Reasons are role-embedded and practice-shaped.

name: Bodhisattva Ethics (Mahayana-leaning)
primary_source: Śāntideva — The Way of the Bodhisattva
description: Ethics aims at alleviating suffering through compassion and wisdom; context-sensitive ‘skillful means’ with strong emphasis on intention and formation.

name: Thomistic Natural Law
primary_source: Thomas Aquinas — Summa Theologiae (selected questions on law and virtue)
description: Objective goods grounded in human nature and final ends; reason discerns norms, including some exceptionless prohibitions, within a virtue-shaped life.

name: Divine Command Voluntarism
primary_source: William of Ockham — selected texts on divine will and obligation
description: Obligation is constituted by God’s commands; moral law is known primarily via revelation (and sometimes natural reason) and is constraint-shaped.

name: Pragmatist Ethics
primary_source: John Dewey — Human Nature and Conduct
description: Ethics is experimental problem-solving; norms are tools revised by inquiry and experience. Growth and reconstruction replace fixed final principles.

name: Existentialist Authenticism
primary_source: Jean-Paul Sartre — Existentialism Is a Humanism
description: No pre-given moral law; values are created through free commitment and lived responsibility. Emphasis on authenticity and situated choice.
